I think this book was aiming to be provocative and shocking and I can appreciate what the author was going for. The premise is that many psychopathic traits (such as ruthlesness and absence of fear) can be the key to success -- as long as they aren't "dialed up too far" as the author describes it. This is obviously true in the business world but I have nothing but disdain for this kind of heartless, cutthroat attitude as displayed in the "anything to get to the top" world of big business CEOs. I don't believe in striving for material success when it comes at the expense of other people (and it always does). I borrowed this book from a friend who is studying criminology. From the perspective of trying to understand human behaviour I was really intrigued by this book. The idea that psychopathy is on a spectrum rather than a yes or no thing is a really important way to view the topic. That being said, I had a lot of issues with the way the book was written. Some of my dislike comes from personal preference (the writing style was too casual for my taste and felt like it was trying too hard to be clever in a lot of places). But most of my dislike came from the author's fundamental lack of understanding when it comes to mental illness and neurodiversity. He used the terms "autistic," "anorexic," "schizophrenic," and "bipolar" as adjectives. (My friend looked up the word schizophrenic and the dictionary does list it as an adjective but I think that usage is dated and insensitive). I'm frustrated with the use of these words as adjectives because they trivialize the struggles of people who actually deal with these conditions. The author also implicitly suggested that autism is a mental illness which it is not (it's a form of neurodivergency). The preface focused on the idea that mental disorders all come with silver linings (which he used as a lead up to explain why psychopathic traits can lead to success). I disagree entirely. Mental disorders can be managed and treated and people with mental disorders often go on to lead happy & satisfying lives. But the disorders themselves are, by definition, maladapative. Here is one example he gave for silver linings :"Even depression has its advantages. Recent research suggests that despondency helps us think better -- and contributes to increased attentiveness and enhanced problem-solving ability. In an ingenious experiment, Joe Forgas, professor of psychology at the University of New South Wales, placed a variety of trinkets, such as toy soldiers, plastic animals, and miniature cars, near the checkout counter of a small stationery store in Sydney. As shoppers made their way out, Forgas tested their memory, asking them to list as many of the items as possible. But there was a catch. On some days the weather was rainy, and Forgas piped Verdi's Requiem through the store; on other days it was sunny and shoppers were treated to a blast of Gilbert and Sullivan. The results couldn't have been clearer: shoppers in the "low mood" condition remembered nearly four times as many of the knickknacks. The rain made them sad, and their sadness made them pay more attention. " I have so many issues with this I don't even know where to start. To equate a low mood with depression is so shockingly ignorant I cannot believe a professor of psychology would make that mistake. Everything about this experiment shows a failure to understand depression. I realize that the experiment was not carried out by the author and the author merely used it as an example to make his point. But the point was offensively and egregiously misinformed.To get to my point -- I learned a few things but I am sure there are more reliable sources out there for learning about psychopathy. Pass me on this one.

This was in equal parts interesting and frustrating. Interesting both in abstract and in content, and some of the tangential topics were the ones that got my attention. But frustrating in that I'm still not sure what Dutton's conclusion was, the structure wasn't the best and reading the notes at the end, I'm not sure the tone of the book was reflective of the author's overall view.I've previously read The Psychopath Test and The Sociopath Next Door, and this was an interesting counterpoint. This had more interviews, in the manner of the former, but written by an academic, there was more scope for personal statements of authority. What I much preferred about this book to Stout's was that there was less in the way of aggregated traits in fictional case studies (my overriding memory of said book), and more in the way of discussion of what makes a psychopath different from the rest of us, bad and not so bad. As Dutton is an academic, I wonder whether I have gone the wrong end of the stick, but there often seemed to be discussions of states of mind similar to that of psychopaths, without a distinction being made* that this was not the same.The first part deals with what a psychopath is, the following chapters are more broadly about psychopaths and life in general. Compared to the other books I've mentioned, there was more discussion of a psychopathy spectrum, and whether it's more appropriate to talk about people with more or fewer psychopathic traits. There was also a look at game theory to explain how psychopaths don't die out. (Incidentally, the maths was a bit too convenient for me to explain a 1% prevalence, and Dutton doesn't explain or dispute Stout's assertion that psychopathy levels are 4% in America and much less in East Asia, instead implying a 1% level across the population except on gender lines). This was indicative of the general attitude of the book - a more scientific starting point was extrapolated without subjecting it to any balance, such as referencing Neil Armstrong's intense concentration after talking about hyper-focused psychopaths.*My misgivings about this book were illustrated in the notes and acknowledgements. Having tried to argue that there are lots of things we can learn from psychopaths, Dutton says "there is nothing remotely funny about them", in a stark manner that contrasts with his generally lighter tone in the main book. There are a couple of clarifications in the notes which give the impression that the aim of this book was to be an 'alternative point of view' rather than a more genuine presentation of an expert's views, and I don't think it was necessary.I don't need a contrarian viewpoint to learn the current generation is less empathic than the last, or to see the main differences in psychopaths' behaviour in certain experiments.I find psychology interesting and for that reason this book was worth reading, and it was original to see an academic's view on the topic, coming from a purely evidence-led perspective. But reading this, I wonder whether this was quite as academic as I'd expected, and was left disappointed. I will have no doubt picked up more traits to identify the mystery villain in the next thriller I read though, which has served me well since reading Stout's and Ronson's efforts.* I'd previously read Martha Stout's review of this book, and though I'd hardly committed it to memory, reading her review again I feel the flaws she'd identified were a similar cause of frustration for me, so perhaps I was primed for them.

The premise is provocative and interesting. Psychopaths have traits that are functional and helpful to us in our lives, in certain contexts. I do agree with the author, there are situations where it would be useful, and he doesn't over reach on the fact its a small amount or small amount of situations - but it does mean walking the same circle for a lot of the book.Unfortunately walking that circle also means trying to square the same circle continously. He alludes too, even pussyfoots round the fact that overall in a ultilitarian perspective you are likely better off, preferring to gush and awe over psychopaths. He points out to the fact the number of psychopaths seems steady at 1% of the population, that in the book "The Evolution Of Cooperation" as well as other examples you come out better by co-operating. Inevitably, short-term, fearless, high-risk decision making runs out of road, particularly with poor inter-personal relationships. Even if it is personally helpful, it is isolated to certain contexts and jobs (which psychopaths do seem to be drawn to) but on a societal level it is catastrophe. 2008 financial crisis anyone? Also the inability for interpersonal connection is a massive issue, and the inability to co-operate effectively is never really tackled well. Again, I don't feel he oversteps his point - but never really plays his own devils advocate, and he should. His laser-focus on his point (very psychopathic) in this creates a book with many holes in it.It is irritating that sometimes he does show differences, but seems to then not go the next step often enough in showing HOW that difference is helpful, or unhelpful. Ok, psychopaths do not go into flight or fight when staring at death - are we sure lack of physical reaction to that helps with survival? And in a majority of scenarios? (I think of Billy Connollys punchline "I dont need to outrun the lion, I just need to outrun you". Someone doped up on adrenaline would certainly have an advantage there). I remain skeptical, but mostly due to lack of evidence. Perhaps this research is just not been done yet. A one-sided account of a fascinating subject:In terms of entertainment value alone, I would give this book 5 stars. Here you have a controversial and rather unique take on one of the most highly stigmatised mental conditions of all time (no surprise given the highly provocative title). Some of the anecdotes are simply fascinating - they had my eyes hopelessly glued to the pages.My problem with this book was the author. He came across as arrogant and appeared to glamourise psychopathy - like he was captivated by it as if it were an abusive partner who could do no wrong. In fact, I got the impression that he was actually just a wannabe psychopath.Sure, there are some valuable lessons that can be learned from people with this condition: stone-cold indifference to the views of others, the ability to think calmly and logically in the face of danger, and living in the moment to name a few. But there are other qualities, such as a glaring nonchalance towards cruelty, extreme selfishness and heartlessness that should not be admired and certainly not encouraged. Dutton made no real attempt to sift through these characteristics and differentiate between the beneficial and the ugly, at least not for SOCIETY AS A WHOLE.And yet, the author gives the impression that all these traits are like, sooooo cool, and omg I wish I was like the psychopathic spies in the mooooviieees. Half the time, it's like reading something from a James Bond fanboy who wants all the admiration and the cool gadgets and the girls, but doesn't actually have the balls to get out there and face the risks. This theme grew more apparent as the book went on and he had yet to interview or even mention any female psychopaths. If he had done this, I probably would've given this book an extra star. But he instead focused solely on male psychopaths and drooled over them. Another thing that grated me was that the term "psychopath" was thrown out there too readily. Indeed, there are people in business, the military, law enforcement, high-end catering etc, who display psychopathic traits - and a higher number of them in these professions than most. But being able to keep your cool in a crisis, to hyper-focus and to compartmentalise and block the emotions out when you choose to, doesn't necessarily make you a psychopath. These traits are also apparent in those with Asperger's syndrome: a different kettle of fish to psychopathy, but with many overlapping traits. And yet this idea was not explored at all.However, despite all the things that annoyed me about this book, I have to say that Dutton is still a talented and engaging writer. Most of his arguments appeared to be well researched and presented in an intelligent yet intelligible way to your average layperson (such as myself). So, would I recommend this book? If you're interested in psychopathy, yeah it's worth a read. Am I going to rave about it? No. All in all an interesting and captivating read, but painfully one sided and written through rose-tinted glasses.

Entertaining in parts but overall a disappointing read.On face value, the intended audience appears to be the lay population, that is, those who do not have any formal education on psychology. With this in mind, there were certainly parts of the book which included too much information.Unfortunately, there were also segments which included excessively descriptive and figurative language. The probleme here is that it took away from or exaggerated the significance of otherwise interesting information. If you have a specific interest in psychopathy like I did then this is perhaps worth a read. In particular the description of Dr Dutton receiving transcranial magnetic stimulion to simulate the neural state of psychopaths was intriguing. However, there may be alternative books on psychopathy like the Psychopath Test which are better.I was left partially informed, partially entertained but wholly unsatisfied.

A rather different take on the biology and psychology of psychopaths – taking it from a more positive viewpoint than most books which are written on this topic are. Psychopaths are often portrayed as being the villains of society, and are associated with less-than-desirable labels (serial killer and the like) although the traits of a psychopath can be found in many disciplines. Probably understandably, as written by the son of a psychopath, Dutton extracts the ways in which psychopathic traits can be beneficial in certain scenarios. He also, correctly in my opinion, presents psychopathy as a spectrum rather than a binary classification and stresses how harnessing the best of a psychopath can consequently bring out the best of a situation. The commonly administered ‘tests of psychopathy’ can be rather amusing too… depending on your outcome I suppose! Well written and well researched, but didn’t quite have the spark with me. 4 stars.

"The Wisdom of Psychopaths" is an interesting account of both those of the past and the present, and how some of their typical traits can have advantages. On the whole, this book was relatively boring. I found that the system of breaking the book up didn't really work, some topics left feeling inconclusive and some lasting for far too long. I could just scan over the words in distraction and had to re-read several passages multiple times. However, I did, to some extent, enjoy the style of narration in the book, as well as certain segments, especially those about the Prisoner's Dilemma and Broadmoor. The rest all just merged into one, nothing notable really standing out. If this was your area of expertise, your true interest in life, I can imagine that this book would be one of your all-time favourites, but that's not for everyone. I didn't hate this book and might read some parts again, but I wouldn't recommend it to those just passing by. It's not that sort of book.

Great concept. I had high hopes for this book and it came short. I felt that the author was taking bits and pieces from all over, crammed them together and then said, "See! My thesis holds water!" He talked about one experiment where he checked the heart rates of subjects watching a horror movie, not even a very good one at that. Yet, he does not tell us if the viewers liked horror, were used to horror, etc. What if one of the participants was an avid horror fan who has seen it all? Does this not skewer his psychopath data? Even his insinuation of Armstrong with psychopathic tendencies. Maybe the reason he did not panic on a moon landing was his vast experiences as a test pilot? Some of the things that man went through in jets would make a moon landing seem like a walk in the park. In the end he never convinced me. The data was shaky at times and at others it seemed selective for his purposes.

Insightful and provocative. Some of a lot of great quotes that reminds us a thing or two : - “I think the problem is that people spend so much time worrying about what might happen, what might go wrong, that they completely lose sight of the present. They completely overlook the fact that, actually, right now, everything's fine. You can see that quite clearly in your interrogation exercise. What was it that chap told you? It's not the violence that breaks you. It's the threat of it. So why not just stay in the moment?”- “Every society needs particular individuals to do its dirty work for it.”- “Psychopathy is like sunlight. Overexposure can hasten one’s demise in grotesque, carcinogenic fashion. But regulated exposure at controlled and optimal levels can have a significant positive impact on well-being and quality of life.”

This book was a very fun read. Nothing was too radical, the science studies were easily digestible. The constant jumping from point to point was facilitated very well by the description of the author's travels to meet with specialists, university professors, and psychopaths themselves, be they con-men, business heads, or institutionalized criminals.Ultimately the idea that if one separates out the personality facets of a psychopath, dilutes them and analyzes them, one finds that the dissociated control a psychopath has over their own psychopathy would be beneficial to an individual. As an introductory primer to these ideas, its' quite succinct; if one was still wondering that they may or may not find a correlation between successful individuals and clinical psychosis, one only need to reread the title.

Dutton cities an analysis that most of the psychopathic attributes are seen in business leaders such as lack of empathy, egocentric, persuasiveness and its evolving in this century. He uses a lot of verbose to promote the view that psychopath may be a positive adaptation. He focused more on the research part on who prepared the questionnaire, where they studied and little did he focus on the wisdom that the title of the book suggests. These seven core principles of psychopathy that, apportioned judiciously and applied with due care and attention, can help us get exactly what we want, can help us respond, rather than react, to the challenges of modern-day living, can transform our outlook from victim to victor, but without turning us into a villain:1. Ruthlessness2. Charm3. Focus4. Mental toughness5. Fearlessness6. Mindfulness7. Action

I found this book fascinating. To be honest, I find psychopathy fascinating in general, particularly functional psychopathy. This book is both engaging and humorous as it walks us through the types of psychopath, the theories behind psychopathy, and the studies that are only starting to scratch the surface of what this complex state is. What is the difference between a brain surgeon and a serial killer? Would you be surprised to know that many special forces operatives score high on the psychopathy scale? I particularly like the notion that psychopathy is an evolutionary trait designed to help our species survive in today's ruthless society - although I doubt evolution works that quickly. I can see how it could very well be interpreted that way. If you like delving into the extremes of personality and the science behind it, this book is for you you.

I was very excited when I picked up this book: its title and book description were very attractive. Yet after finishing two chapters and reading later chapters of the book, I still wasn't clear on the arguments the author was making. I may be wrong since I didn't complete the book, but Dutton seemed to be going in circles talking about the same things, not offering anything new. Anecdotes are interesting, but dumping anecdotes one after another serves little purpose. Anecdotes interspersed with meaningful analyses would do much better. A 3 star rating in view of how I didn't finish this book. But what a waste, the idea behind the book was fascinating. This book had a lot of potential to do better than it turned out to be. Dutton could do it justice to write in clearer, concise sentences.

- mankind selects the best moderator as their leader and support him to maintain the peace.- psychopaths have very sensitive emotion. They just forget about it because they focus on their goal too much. It can be called ‘flow’ or ‘golden triangle’- People need to practice to get into ‘flow’ stage but psychopaths are naturally born with it. Natural born monks.- ‘Maha-satipattana Sutta’, practice mindfulness. Not consider about the future nor past but focus on the present. Emptying mind.- Being psychopath is not like black and white. It’s more like density. Mid range of psychopathic ability has the highest ability to perform in various ways. Functional psychopath.- Psychopaths help people who need help more than normal people.- To be a hero, you need a psychopathic ability.

Psychopaths, they are our murders and serial killers, but did you know they also manage your bank accounts and run highly successful fortune 500 companies? Well that's the themes of this book. It goes through in some technical detail how there are different levels of psychopathy, and what perks it gives to people. There are those who uses this "gift" of psychopathy to not harm others, but live a relatively normal life among us. Highly skillful, highly personable, and highly competitive, they stand out among the crowds, but only they know it. If you have interest in psychology, this book is worth picking up. Although you may start wishing you had a few of these psychopathic qualities by the end of the book.

Took me forever to read this. It just wasn't interesting, not organized in any kind of logical way that I could tell; chapters were super long (which always kinda turns me off), the author liked using really big words and complex phrases that just made it kind of a slog to get through, seemingly in a pedantic attempt to seem clever. Some of the stuff was interesting. I was really excited by the idea of this book, it just wasn't what I expected. Also: FOOTNOTES SUCK. omg, so many footnotes. Footnotes everywhere. I think that was one of the reasons I didn't enjoy reading it--your train of thought is constantly interrupted by having to go read the friggin footnote, which in most cases could have just been easily incorporated into the text.

A very interesting book full of well-founded information. Contrary to what most people think, psychopathy is not an exclusive peronality disturbance of people who commit heinous crimes. Our society is full of people with these personality traits. Just look more closely at the people at the top of the political / business career. You'll be frightened by how many people are socially functioning psychopaths.Therefore, I greatly appreciated the time the author devoted to the research being done on psychopaths adapted to society. I found the short space devoted to the saints very interesting, and was surprised by the outcome of the empathy investigation.I highly recommend this book to anyone who likes Personality Disorders and who enjoys science-based books.

“I think the problem is that the people spend so much time worrying about what might happen, what might go wrong, that they completely lose sight of the present. They completely overlook the fact that, actually, right now, everything’s perfectly fine. You can see that quite clearly in your interrogation exercise. What was it that chap told you? It’s not the violence that breaks you. It’s the threat of it. So why not just stay in the moment?”I appreciate this book for all its insights, mentioned experiments and stories or/and examples regarding the topic. Some parts definitely made me chuckle. The method pf the author, imparting knowledge while adding some humour is, I think, effective for me.

So, this book is about how some psychopathic qualities can be helpful to your average day to day life, which is an interesting take, as from this book it appears that "psychopaths just have to much of a one good thing." Dutton has so many examples and explains why having theses qualities would benefit others. But he never said how we can make the more positive traits of the psychopath into our own. he explains that they are just born that way, but he spend so much of the book showing a number of examples and benefits of this. But never how. That aside, the book spend way to much time on Special Forces agents, cops and of course James bound. For me it felt like he was just filling pages with example after example. 2.5 starts

“What if our better nature wasn't better after all? But was instead, well, just nature?”This was such an amazing book! Not only was it extremely gripping but I also managed to learn a couple of new things. Although I quite enjoyed reading it, I do think that the book has a couple of flaws - the author didn't organize information in the best way possible and some things didn't seem that accurate (for example the author mentioning that his father was a psychopath although that was purely his own opinion). Overall it was an interesting read, I liked Dutton's writing style and I think reading this book allowed me to see people with antisocial personality disorder in a different, more positive light.

An entertaining book with lots of real life stories and references to research in the field. Dutton proposes that perhaps we all have psychopathy to varying degrees. He gives the seven parameters of psychopathy as ruthlessness, charm, focus, mental toughness, fearlessness, mindfulness, and action. A true psychopath would have all of these parameters maxed out. Functional psychopaths are all around us and, in particular, in certain job areas more than others. Top of the list includes CEOs, Lawyers, Media People, Sales people and Surgeons. He explains both the PCL-R and PPI tests for Psychopathy

Reviewing information from my studies, this sort of read is again typical of me. I felt this fell short, it neither delved deep into the depths of psychopathy - for good or bad. A very brief introduction. I thought he could have done more with the psychopaths he met in terms of understanding their thought processes in problem solving (towards the back end of the book). He could have asked more things of them, got more examples and gave us a better understanding of who they were. Its an interesting read without being my go-to text on the subject.

The book had a problem from the start in my opinion with the test they perform to distinguish psychopaths from non-psychopaths. Some behavious might be attributes to psychopathy but this is a range-as the author also says actually. Defining people with couple of questions, grouping them and making shaky data out of this is not science. Seing thise graphs with no statisticalanalysis makes me cringe every time and makes me believe less is “social sciences” These aside, he makes a point about the functioning psychos in our life, which makes sense to me.

The word psychopath looks to have a vague definition and it looks like an over generalization of many things combined. In that sense, i don't believe we should take this word too seriously.Yet, thinking about psychopatic traits seems to be important, considering that those who have those traits are around us and they have big impact in society we live in; whether they're a soldier, killer, lawyer, ceo, surgeon (or maybe someone close?).This book made me think about that, it's well written, interesting and i liked it.

There is a lot to chew on. From killers and con men to presidents and CEO's. It was a far more entertaining read than expected. A lot of science jargon mixed with great storytelling. Thought provoking and a good starting point for self-reflection about your own beliefs about how you treat people or how you have been treated by people in your life.There are a number of books mentioned in the book that ended up on my GR list. The adventure into the psychopathic mind is not over.Very enjoyable read.

So this book reads more or less like a psychology text book, not that there is anything wrong with that. This is nonfiction after all, but i can understand why some people would not like this book given how technical it is. The big take away I got from reading this book is that the human mind is a vastly complicated thing and not everything is as it would seem. This book also focuses on the more functional aspects of psychopathy which is pretty interesting. If you have an interest in psychology and the darker aspects of it then you should read this book.

First audiobook of the year. The human mind is crazy computer and like all computers it can go haywire sometimes. We have this pretty narrow view of someone that is a psychopath. A ruthless emotionless killer. What surprised me the most was the part about anxieties and how psychopaths deal with them. We live in an extremely fast paced time and I think people are just not equipped to deal with so much stress. Psychopaths are completely indifferent to such stressful things which is quite interesting.

I found this book extremely interesting. There is a connotation that psychopaths are these evil horrible people. According to the human mind and how it works, we all have a little psychopath in us. These psychopathic traits aren’t always bad as many of those who would selflessly defend us are high on the psychopath spectrum. Anything regarding the human mind and how it functions is so interesting to me. Learning how a psychopath’s mind works is incredible. I need to up my inner psychopath... for the correct occasions only. 😁

Could be better. Very anecdotal yet the author often generalizes something as specific to all psychopaths just because it happened to a person he knew who he thought was a psychopath.I very much doubt the electric pulse to the brain experiment which lets you have the same mindset of a psychopath. If that would really work it would most likely be used by many.All in all, some good advices though on how to copy the positive traits of the functioning psychopaths and why you don't ever want to be a full blown one. In general, it all boils down to mindfullness combined with stoicism.

After reading this book I got an idea that in order to succeed I have to be psycopath 😲😅 ...well not actually be psycopath but learn from them:1. To make decisions coolly and rationally even in stressful and chaotic environments 2. To be charming and intelligent, have no fears3. To take actions4. Live in the here and now (like Zen masters)5. To be able to change behaviour depending on the situation.Some psychopaths end up in jail as murderers and rapists, but others are successful executives, lawyers and surgeons and hold high political offices.

Fascinating and compelling. Believe it fully. Always a positive to each evolutionary extreme. I can think of a couple folks I will out in this category...Seven deadly wins:RuthlessnessCharmFocusMental toughnessFearlessness Mindfulness Action"What the psychopath believes he needs to protest against turns out to be human life itself"Psychopaths share same spiritual qualities of fearlessness and mental toughness

This one from Kevin came in a little above me at the time of reading. I found it a struggle to get through where I breezed through 'The Good Psychopath's Guide to Success'. Granted it was a few years ago that I read it, and perhaps I didn't have the attention span I do now (then I was around goldfish, now I'm somewhere around a dog surrounded by food and toys).Well worth the read, if nothing else it's interesting material

It's a readable book, moderately entertaining, but I think the "psychopathy may be adaptive" thing may be a bit lost on us New Yorkers. I went to a top law school and I work at a nonprofit near Wall Street and I'm all too aware of how society rewards psychopathic or sociopathic behavior; more interesting to me is how we can change society for the better. Verged on glamorizing at times, but again, well-written and entertaining in its way.

There are some interesting bits and pieces of information in here, but this book should be taken with a grain of salt. Mr. Dutton doesn't exactly have the cleanest academic record and doesn't work within this area of research. Additionally, this book is peppered with his own quips and asides or opinions on what psychopathy is. You can't have that if you're attempting to produce a scientific and validated piece of literature.

I finally finished this torture of a book by Dutton. I agree with much of this criticism:https://t.co/IjKz3a9qxPIn short: superficially convincing, but lacking any depth. Twisting existing research to the point of nonsense, for the sake of controversy.The only reason I finished it is to find the tidbits of information buried in the mountains of disingenuous logic.Still gets 2 stars because I did read it to the end.

It started very promising and informative. Then it became too deep and technical for me. I was hoping to learn some key insights but was taken into studies and research. The interesting thing is that it shows everyone is unique and take about ways different traits can be helpful (e.g., a surgeon not being emotionally involved and invested). I read the first few chapters and skimmed through the rest.

This was an interesting book, although it's not the kind you would talk about out loud without getting weird looks. I just love the kind of books that make me see things in a different perspective, and this was one of it. I find it of high accuracy, it explains few misconceptions about what psychopathy means (example how people assume all criminals are psychopaths, because it's hard for them to admit that the human nature also has its darkness). I have to admit I did not know the difference between psychopathy and antisocial personality disorder or sadistic personality disorder and I'm glad this books made things clear for me. I enjoyed the stories more than the statistics and details of the experiments (but I understand their importance in clinical psychology). I'm interested in reading Kevin Dutton's other books too when I find them.

Activating your inner psycho?I really enjoy this book. The author who is also a Prof in psychology tells us that it’s not a bad thing to have psychotic traits in us, in fact, you need it in order to survive and to succeed. I had also tried some of the decision making scenario with my friends to determine whether they are normal, or borderline psychotic and the results did amaze me.

The topic was interesting but the writer for it wasn't right. It took me almost two months to read just because of the writing style and the pace was so slow, I got bored every few pages. I would have enjoyed it more if it would have been written a little better and not using so much hard to pronounce words that you had to google to even understand the topic at hand. But overall some of the things were interesting to read because human behavior is truly interesting sometimes.

The bad news is that psychopaths have a leg up us normal people by not being phased when things do not go their way while being driven towards success. That’s why you find non violent psychopaths in the top of every profession. The good news is that normal people can emulate psychopaths by being saints. Praying gives whatever we are to the Divine so we can be present to the hear and now and in flow doing what we need to do in the moment. Have a goal in mind but concentrate on the process.

This book provides interesting insight into psychopathy and explores the idea that psychopathic traits, in moderation, can provide us with considerable advantages in navigating daily life. Though what exactly this "moderation" means is unclear and likely varies with circumstances and morality.Certainly informative and entertaining, but one can't be faulted for thinking that the author is more than a little in love with psychopaths, at some point even likening them to superheroes and sages.

I think it makes a very good psychology and neuroscience book: very technical, detailed /!; informative.And yet, i think the title is giving people the wrong impression to read this book. Unlike the title, which is kinda eyecatching and bold, the findings and conclusion drawn in the book is rather mellow and safe👇that we are all complicated beings, our minds are hard to read, psychopathic traits and high performance traits have something in common but no necessarily mean anything.....

Book focused on activities (good and bad) where psychopaths are high achievers. It's a different look at the world we live in. There are a lot of practical advice through the stories such as grit, focus, and cunning. Many of the most successful presidents, politicians, and CEOs have psychopathic leanings so it can be helpful to learn how to harness your inner psycho.

Although mostly interesting, and with scientific content, it was disappointing on the whole. Rather a collection of information than a cursive recital. Rather a promise than an acquisition. Somehow, Dutton failed to reach the end point, or draw the bottom line. The initial seduction does not escalate - the reader's expectations are not fully met at the end of this reading journey.

Very good book. The author clearly did a lot of work on it. The bibliography is rich with references to real science papers and research.If you want to have a nice introduction to the Big Five Personality Traits, Dark Traits and understand what is the relationship between them with psychopaths this is a nice book to go. It's a summary of years of research. And the writing is really good.

This book was totally unexpectedly good and surprisingly technical. You need a bit of psychological background to understand some very subtle details. In the end it makes you think twice and it makes you doubt a bit. Saints, serials killers, monks, Buddhist, all are treated in this book. All in all we all are a bit psychopaths in the spectrum of psychopathy.
The Good Psychopath's Guide to SuccessThis book is a psychological and personal development. It's a great book and I learned stuff about me and my personality and I encourage you to read it too.

I'm having a hard time to write anything about this book. Mostly because for me it was OK. Nothing less, nothing more. It is in the middle. Not boring enough to put it down, but I was continuing it mostly because I wanted to finish. I didn't learn that much from it, but it was written well enough to keep me engaged in some way. So yeah. It is just OK (goodreads 2 starts are marked as OK).

Thoroughly engrossing and an enjoying scientific read that is easy to understand. The concept is that despite having a bad rep, psychopaths have a lot to teach us - if their skills can be applied in moderation. Some of the psychopaths featured are downright chilling but the book is overall a positive one.

Have you ever been in a life or death situation? That's psychopathy baby! In a good sense of course 😉Nice readEye openingsEtc...

a fun and informative book. would definetely recommend it. i really liked how the book explained the positive side of psychopathic traits, what we can learn from psycopaths as well as how these traits are needed in alot of jobs to be succesful. the book also clarified how having psychopathic traits doesnt necessarily mean becoming a serial killer.

Jon Ronson’s book on psychopaths is still my fave, but this takes a different look that’s worthwhile. Psychopath qualities can be useful in certain jobs, such as bomb squad workers. Risk taking free from anxiety has helped our society move forward in many cases, and it doesn’t necessarily lead to serial killing.

The author does a good job explaining how Psychopaths aren't all killers and have an essential role in our lives. And he makes a great point to explain how that is. He mentions shoulder and doctors in his book, which is extremely true. I definitely suggest everyone to read it. It has an enlightening point and allows us to view the subject with an open mind.

I would say overall this book was pretty good. Some insightful studies and questions about the nature of psychopathy and it’s influence on society. The only part that I personally didn’t like is that it was really jumpy, switching from the narrative to studies. If each chapter was just a collection of studies in a more expository format it might have been easier to read.

My current rating is based on the assumption that the information presented was valid - it certainly did seem like it, but it's quite a bit to just take for granted. After my confirmations, I'll be editing the review.

Full of crazy interesting psychological studies...too full. Not enough relevant human examples, or ways to digest the information from the studies into real life examples. The Psychopath Test by Ronson is a way better choice. A lot more readable than this one.

Excellent. Gives a neuroscience perspective (but easy to read) on psychopathy. Provides research outcomes, also. A very interesting perspective that I found helpful for everyday dealings with people and for myself. I highly recommend it.

This was an interesting book. Very methodical in its research and its presentation. I really enjoyed the insights regarding the research on Buddhist monks and their ability to "control themselves" to a much more heightened degree than any of the other specialized groups presented in the book.

Author gave a great inside story, how psychopaths see this world, and how you won't notice, who is actually I psychopath. And also, that the meaning psychopath, doesn't always have to be a bad. Great book, recommend it to everybody!

Overall kinda meh. Had a few 'huh' moments and shared some tidbits. But I found the more I talked about it the less I agreed with some of the author's methods or conclusions. Zero reference or mention of any female psychopaths. Not even a paragraph explaining why he wasn't including them.

Well written, definitely holds your attention and has you asking who you know that is and if maybe you are a psychopath... or if you should strive to emulate them just a little for those especially heart stopping moments.

A bit hard to get through. Had I read this, I may have skimmed or never finished. But that is not to say that it wasn't interesting! There were a lot of great studies intermixed with psychopaths he knew, or went to visit. Overall pretty interesting.

Very interesting look into the mind of psychopaths and how they differ (even among themselves). Would have like more focus on actionable ways to use the "good" psychopathic qualities in everyday life, but otherwise really enjoyed this one.

This was.... Weird. I need to take a few days off to think about it but will come with a review once I have cleared my thoughts on it.It was very informative, somewhat educational and it put psychopaths in a new light for me.

It is a good confidence booster. If you apply some of the ideas covered by the book on how to control your feelings everything becomes more clear in the daily life. Not an easy thing to, practice is the key or a life goal that is influenced heavily by this.

Kinda tries to be a pop psy book but falls a little flat. Interesting info, odd delivery. It felt like the subjects, psychopaths, were plasticized a little bit. The author dips his toe into self-help without committing fully, which makes some of the theories wishy-washy.

The book dwells on the idea of psychopathy and really used very interesting example such as President Bill Clinton whom has very high scores in this questionnaire. It also conducts lots of research about how psychopath being and sometimes shocks researchers in their scored empathy.
